chapter_title: PLAY A SUCKER TO CATCH A SUCKER—SEEM DUMBER THAN YOUR MARK
summary: In this chapter, the author explores the strategy of appearing less intelligent than your target, allowing them to feel superior. By disarming your mark's suspicions through a façade of ignorance, you can manipulate their confidence to achieve your objectives. The narrative of Asbury Harpending’s encounter with prospectors showcases how Arnold and Slack deceived financiers by playing the role of simpletons. This tactic not only secured their trust but also led to their eventual downfall when the truth was revealed. Ultimately, the art of deception hinges on projecting a persona that prompts others to underestimate your true capabilities.

slides.section_body: To manipulate others, make them feel smarter than you. This strategy disarms their suspicions and allows for more freedom in deception. By fostering an illusion of superiority, you create an opportunity for yourself to operate undetected.
slides.quote: ‘The trick, then, is to make your victims feel smart—and not just smart, but smarter than you are.’

slides.section_body: The story of Harpending and the diamond mine illustrates how appearances can deceive even the most astute financiers. Arnold and Slack’s ability to play the fool allowed them to execute one of the biggest frauds of their time.
slides.quote: ‘Who knows if Janin is right, they told the prospectors; the mine may not be as rich as we think.’

slides.section_body: Winning trust is about projecting a persona that elicits confidence from others. Simple, naive behavior can mask true intentions, allowing you to outsmart those who underestimate you.
slides.quote: ‘The feeling that someone else is more intelligent than we are is almost intolerable.’

slides.section_body: Superiority breeds resentment in social dynamics. By downplaying your abilities, you can navigate social situations without triggering jealousy or defensiveness.
slides.quote: ‘It is exceedingly rash to let others see that you are decidedly superior to them intellectually.’

slides.section_title: Playing the Part: A Case Study
slides.section_body: Bismarck’s game of quinze is an excellent example of employing foolishness to mislead opponents. Through reckless play, he projected an image that concealed his strategic mind.
slides.quote: ‘He believed me to be more venturesome than I am and I gave way.’

slides.section_body: Adopting an air of simplicity can disarm your opponents, allowing you to operate unnoticed among them. When you appear non-threatening, you can achieve your goals with less opposition.
slides.quote: ‘Masquerading as a swine to kill the tiger.’

slides.section_body: Just as intelligence can be downplayed, so can sophistication. By making others feel more cultured, you further build rapport and diminish their defenses.
slides.quote: ‘Always make people believe they are smarter and more sophisticated than you are.’

slides.section_body: Wielding ignorance can be a powerful tactic. Demonstrating naivety can foster a sense of superiority in others, increasing your opportunities to deceive.
slides.quote: ‘The best way to be well received by all is to clothe yourself in the skin of the dumbest of brutes.’

slides.section_body: While it’s essential to appear less intelligent, in certain situations revealing intelligence can cover up deception. Knowing when to shift your approach is crucial.
slides.quote: ‘If you seem to have authority and knowledge, people will believe what you say.’

slides.section_body: The trick to effective deception lies in mastering your appearance. By knowing when to play dumb and when to showcase intelligence, one can navigate social hierarchies successfully.
slides.quote: ‘The wisest man plays the card of stupidity at times.’
